    Highlights

    •
    trans-Differentiation of cytotoxic Th17 to Th1 cells promotes liver pathology
    •
    CX3CR1+CD8Teff cells inhibit fibrosis by granzyme-mediated killing of fibroblasts
    •
    Defective induction of hepatic B cell tolerance promotes autoimmunity in infants
    •
    B-cell-modifying therapies promote immune recovery in infants with biliary atresia

    Summary

    Biliary atresia (BA) is a severe cholangiopathy that leads to liver failure in infants, but its pathogenesis remains to be fully characterized. By single-cell RNA profiling, we observed macrophage hypo-inflammation, Kupffer cell scavenger function defects, cytotoxic T cell expansion, and deficiency of CX3CR1+effector T and natural killer (NK) cells in infants with BA. More importantly, we discovered that hepatic B cell lymphopoiesis did not cease after birth and that tolerance defects contributed to immunoglobulin G (IgG)-autoantibody accumulation in BA. In a rhesus-rotavirus induced BA model, depleting B cells or blocking antigen presentation ameliorated liver damage. In a pilot clinical study, we demonstrated that rituximab was effective in depleting hepatic B cells and restoring the functions of macrophages, Kupffer cells, and T cells to levels comparable to those of control subjects. In summary, our comprehensive immune profiling in infants with BA had educed that B-cell-modifying therapies may alleviate liver pathology.

    Graphical Abstract

    Keywords

    1. biliary atresia
    2. scRNA-seq
    3. cytotoxicity
    4. CX3CR1
    5. B cell haematopoiesis
    6. autoantibody
    7. TNFSF13B
    8. hypo-inflammation
    9. Rituximab

    Introduction

    Biliary atresia (BA) is a severe cholangiopathy mediated by extrahepatic bile duct obstruction, causing pathological jaundice and liver failure in early infancy (Asai et al., 2015

    Pang, S.Y. ∙ Dai, Y.M. ∙ Zhang, R.Z. ...
    Autoimmune liver disease-related autoantibodies in patients with biliary atresia
    World J. Gastroenterol. 2018; 24:387-396
    Crossref
    Scopus (23)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Notwithstanding the above information, a comprehensive description of immune dysfunction that leads to rapid liver failure in infants with BA has yet to be established.
    In this study, we profiled mononuclear immune cells (granulocyte depleted) from liver biopsies and blood of infants with BA, and compared the profiles with those of control subjects at single-cell resolution. We identified 42 cell subsets encompassing tissue-resident and circulating conventional (CD4+ and CD8+ T) and unconventional (natural killer T [NKT], mucosal-associated invariant T [MAIT], gamma-delta T [γδT]) T cells, B cells, innate lymphoid cells (natural killer [NK], type 1 innate lymphoid cells [ILC1s]), monocytes, macrophages, dendritic cells (DCs), and Kupffer cells. Importantly, we showed that B cell lymphopoiesis in the liver was extended beyond birth, persisting through at least the first few months of life. These B cells formed a functional hub, and their dysregulation contributed to autoantibody accumulation and liver failure in infants with BA. We provided pre-clinical and clinical evidence showing that B-cell-modifying therapies may be used to restore liver immune function for infants with BA.

    Results

    Cohort Characterization and Single-Cell RNA (scRNA) Survey of Immune Cells from Blood and Liver Biopsies of Infants with BA

    We studied two cohorts of children: one with BA and the other with choledochal cysts (CC). Both required surgical operations for bile drainage but had contrasting clinical prognoses. BA was diagnosed when the intrahepatic biliary tree and/or the extrahepatic bile duct cannot be observed during intraoperative cholangiography. CC was diagnosed according to cystic dilation of the common bile duct due to malformations at the intersection of the bile and the pancreatic ducts. On retrospective examination of the electronic medical records of BA (n = 927), CC (n = 248), physiologic jaundice (n = 9,297), and healthy subjects (n = 2,471), we found that infants with BA had persistently elevated concentrations of r-glutamyl transferase (r-GT), alanine aminotransferase (ALT), aspartate aminotransferase (AST), total bile acid (TBA), and direct bilirubin (DBIL) (Figures 1A and 1B), consistent with advanced liver pathology. In contrast, laboratory indices and long-term prognosis of patients with CC were comparable to those of the healthy control subjects. To deduce immune pathogenesis of infants with BA, we chose CC as well as non-cholestatic subjects with normal liver function as control subjects (Figure 1C).
    Notably, indirect bilirubin (IBIL) concentrations in infants with BA were significantly lower than those in infants with physiological jaundice (Figure S1A). Thus, the combined values of decreased IBIL with increased r-GT, ALT, AST, TBA, and DBIL could potentially offer an additional biomarker for the detection of patients with BA to distinguish them from those with physiological jaundice or CC (Figure S1B). Critically, nearly 50% of patients will require liver transplantation within one year after Kasai's operation (Figure S1C). Therefore, there is a serious need for more effective treatments.
    To identify immune changes associated with BA, we generated 159,622 high-quality single-cell transcriptomes for immune cells (CD45+ cells excluding granulocytes) from 6 BA, 6 CC (control-CC), and 4 non-cholestatic (control-other) control subjects (Figure 1D). Single-cell V(D)J profiling of T and B cells was also performed for each of the 16 subjects. After data pre-processing and quality control, immune cells were partitioned into 11 major clusters (Figures 1E and 1F). Cell clustering was based on shared expression features of known marker genes. All cellular subsets had representative cells from each individual sample. Batch effects were negligible (Figure S1D). Sub-clustering analysis revealed 42 subsets (Figure S1E). Transcriptional features and candidate ligand-receptor pairs for all subsets were provided (Tables S1, S2, and S3).

    Deficiency of CX3CR1-Expressing T and NK Cells Contributes to Liver Fibrosis in Infants with BA

    We identified 5 populations of innate lymphocytes (ILCs), comprising KLRD1+NCAM1dimCX3CR1+ circulating NK cells (cir-NK), KLRD1+NCAM1+ CX3CR1−CD69+ liver-resident NK cells (lr-NK), IFNG-expressing lrNK (lr-NK-IFNGhi), IL7R+TCF7+SELL+KLRD1+NCAM1+ ILC1-like cells, and IL7R+ TCF7+SELL+KLRD1loKIT+AHR+LTB+ lymphoid tissue inducer (LTi) cells. Two subsets of unconventional T cells, namely the KLRD1+CX3CR1+CD3D+ circulating NKT (cir-NKT) cells and the KLRD1+CX3CR1-CD3D+CD69+ liver-resident NKT (lr-NKT) cells, clustered closely with the ILCs and were analyzed in parallel (Figures 3A and 3B; Figure S4A).
    The proportions of CX3CR1-expressing cir-NK and cir-NKT cells were also significantly decreased in liver biopsies of infants with BA (Figures S4B and S4C). Similar to the CX3CR1+CD8Teff cells, cir-NK cells were also enriched with genes that promote migration and interaction with non-lymphoid cells in comparison to lr-NK cells (Figures S4D and S4E). Interestingly, ASCL2 and KLF2 were also active in cir-NK cells (Figure 3C; Figure S4F).     Hepatic Macrophages Have Decreased Inflammatory and Phagocytic Function in Infants with BA

    We identified 9 subsets of myeloid cells, including 3 monocyte subsets (CD14+, CD16+, and CD14+CD16+ monocytes), 3 DC subsets (CLEC9A+CD141+XCR1+ cDC1, CD1C+ cDC2, and pDC), Kupffer cells (CD5L+C1QA+C1QB+MARCO+VSIG4+), and mitotic myeloid cells (MKI67+PCNA+) (Figures 4A and 4B). cDC1 and Kupffer cells were mainly detected in the liver (Figure 4C). When comparing BA with control subjects, we found that inflammation and chemotaxis were markedly suppressed in myeloid cells of infants with BA (Figure 4D). In addition, Kupffer cells from infants with BA exhibited decreased expression of scavenger genes (MARCO and CD5L) (Figure 4D). This was also validated in vitro, in which Kupffer cells from infants with BA were markedly impaired in their ability to engulf fluorescent-labeled Escherichia coli (Figure 4E).
    To confirm macrophage hypo-inflammation, we measured concentrations of cytokines in liver biopsy homogenates. The majority of the inflammatory cytokines, except for IL-32, TNFSF8 (CD30L), Chitinase-3-like 1 (CHI3L1), TNFSF13B (B-cell activation factor [BAFF]), IL-8, and MMP-2, were significantly decreased in liver biopsies of infants with BA compared with those of control subjects (Figure 4F).     B Cell Lymphopoiesis and Tolerance Defects Contribute to Expansion of Autoreactive B Cells in Infants with BA

    Hematopoiesis in the liver occurs in the human fetus but ceases soon after birth (Holt and Jones, 2000

    To validate hepatic B cell lymphopoiesis, we performed bulk RNA-seq of HSCs, and the developing B cells sorted respectively from liver biopsies, bone marrows, and PBMCs (Figure 5C). In the liver and bone marrow, transcriptional profiles of the counterpart B cells were nearly identical at their respective developmental stages (Figures S5C and S5D). To further confirm the above findings in situ, we performed immunofluorescent staining and showed that RAG1 and RAG2 were expressed in the pro-, pre-, and immature B cells (shown as CD10+ B cells) in liver biopsies of both BA and control subjects (Figure 5D). Furthermore, we showed that although the proportions of developing CD10+ B cells declined with age, B cell lymphopoiesis nevertheless continued at least through the first 4 months after birth (Figure 5E).
    Studies of human bone marrow B cells have suggested that the majority of the pre-B and immature B cells possess self-reactive B cell receptors (BCRs). Exit of these B cells from the bone marrow to the periphery requires depletion of the high-affinity BCRs in a process known as central tolerance (Nemazee, 2017
    62.
    Nemazee, D.
    Mechanisms of central tolerance for B cells
    Nat. Rev. Immunol. 2017; 17:281-294

    Google Scholar
    ). We hypothesized that an infectious insult could activate the autoreactive pre-B and immature B cells and predispose infants to autoimmune liver damage. Autoreactive BCRs have been reported to have increased lengths and positively charged amino acids of the heavy chain CDR3 regions (Wardemann et al., 2003
    92.
    Wardemann, H. ∙ Yurasov, S. ∙ Schaefer, A. ...
    Predominant autoantibody production by early human B cell precursors
    Science. 2003; 301:1374-1377
    Crossref
    Scopus (1642)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). We did not observe substantially altered CDR3 lengths or impaired V(D)J recombination in BA compared with control subjects (Figures S5E and S5F). However, somatic hypermutation (SHM) in the variable regions (Figure 5F) and class switch recombination (CSR) (Figure 5G) were visibly decreased in the memory B, PB, and PC populations in infants with BA compared with control subjects. The decreased CSR might be related to elevated expression of TNFSF8 (CD30L) by T and NK cells in infants with BA (Figure 5H). CD30 engagement in a hypo-inflammatory environment has been shown to suppress CD40-mediated CSR of human naive B cells (Cerutti et al., 1998
    11.
    Cerutti, A. ∙ Schaffer, A. ∙ Shah, S. ...
    CD30 is a CD40-inducible molecule that negatively regulates CD40-mediated immunoglobulin class switching in non-antigen-selected human B cells
    Immunity. 1998; 9:247-256
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (65)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ).

    Accumulation of Autoreactive IgGs in the Liver of Infants with BA

    To further confirm that B cell lymphopoiesis and tolerance defects contributed to BA pathogenesis, we first measured the serum concentrations of the immunoglobulin isotypes. We found that an increased IgM: IgG4 ratio was associated with significantly prolonged jaundice-free survival after Kasai’s operation in infants with BA (Figure 6A). In subsequent analysis of autoantibody involvement, we found that subjects with BA had significantly decreased IgM- but increased IgG-specific autoantibodies to multiple cytosolic and nuclear self-antigens (Figure 6B). Self-reactive natural IgM autoantibodies have been shown to protect against microbial invasion, facilitate removal of apoptotic cells, and prevent autoimmune destruction of host cells (Lobo, 2016
    50.
    Lobo, P.I.
    Role of Natural Autoantibodies and Natural IgM Anti-Leucocyte Autoantibodies in Health and Disease
    Front. Immunol. 2016; 7:198
    Crossref
    Scopus (79)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). IgG autoantibodies with high affinity to self-antigens, in contrast, can cause tissue damage and autoimmune disease development (Siloşi et al., 2016
    78.
    Siloşi, I. ∙ Siloşi, C.A. ∙ Boldeanu, M.V. ...
    The role of autoantibodies in health and disease
    Rom. J. Morphol. Embryol. 2016; 57:633-638
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Of the B-cell-modifying cytokines that were elevated in liver biopsies of infants with BA (Figure 6C), BAFF (encoded by TNFSF13B) concentrations were positively correlated with Sjögren's-syndrome-related antigen A (Ro/SSA)-specific IgG concentrations in the liver (Figure 6D). This finding is consistent with published studies showing that BAFF promoted the survival of IgG+ autoreactive B cells (Lesley et al., 2004
    46.
    Lesley, R. ∙ Xu, Y. ∙ Kalled, S.L. ...
    Reduced competitiveness of autoantigen-engaged B cells due to increased dependence on BAFF
    Immunity. 2004; 20:441-453
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (484)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) and accumulation of Ro/SSA-specific IgGs in patients with autoimmune diseases (Mariette et al., 2003
    57.
    Mariette, X. ∙ Roux, S. ∙ Zhang, J. ...
    The level of BLyS (BAFF) correlates with the titre of autoantibodies in human Sjögren’s syndrome
    Ann. Rheum. Dis. 2003; 62:168-171
    Crossref
    Scopus (487)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). The above findings were additionally supported by the expression of autoreactive Ro/SSA-specific BCRs in hepatic B cells (Figure 6E).

    B-Cell-Modifying Therapies Ameliorate Liver Pathology in an RRV-Induced BA Mouse Model

    Apart from producing autoantibodies, B cells may also modify the functions of T, NK, and myeloid cells through MHC-mediated antigen presentation or soluble mediators (Figure 6F). We wanted to test whether B-cell-modifying therapies could potentially ameliorate liver damage in an RRV-induced BA mouse model in neonatal BALB/c mice. First, we showed that hepatic B cell lymphopoiesis was present in 11-day-old BALB/c mice (Figure S6A). Next, we found that depletion of B cells by an anti-CD20 antibody, or more strikingly blocking MHC-class-II- or MHC-class-I-mediated antigen presentation, significantly improved weight gain and decreased jaundice occurrence compared with untreated RRV mice (Figures 6G and 6H). The improved treatment efficacy of anti-MHC-class-I/-II therapy suggested additional contributions of antigen-presenting cells to BA pathogenesis.
    Despite the improved outcomes above, 60.6% (20/33) of anti-CD20-treated RRV mice still developed jaundice. These jaundiced mice had increased B1-a, pre-pro-B cells (Figure S6B) and IFN-γ+ CD4 and CD8 T cells (Figure 6I) in the liver compared with the jaundice-free RRV-mice. Thus, depletion efficacy of B cells and abundance of pre-B cells may account for the heterogeneity in response outcomes. Of note, anti-CD20 or anti-MHC-mediated therapies did not impair RRV clearance of the infected mice (Figure S6C).
    We also found that the concentrations of hepatic Cx3cl1 and C1q (which suppresses autoreactive CD8+ T cells activation) (Ling et al., 2018
    49.
    Ling, G.S. ∙ Crawford, G. ∙ Buang, N. ...
    C1q restrains autoimmunity and viral infection by regulating CD8+ T cell metabolism
    Science. 2018; 360:558-563
    Crossref
    Scopus (129)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) were significantly increased in anti-CD20- or anti-MHC-treated jaundice-free RRV mice (Figure S6D). Kupffer cell numbers and scavenger function were also enhanced after treatment (Figure S6E). Histologically, lymphocytic infiltration around the liver portal area was decreased and the lobular structures were more intact in the treated RRV mice (Figure S6F). At the same time, liver fibrosis, as shown by Masson’s trichrome staining, was reduced in treated compared with untreated RRV mice (Figure S6G).

    Rituximab Administration Effectively Depleted B Cells, Dampened T Cell Cytotoxicity, and Improved Scavenger Function of Kupffer Cells

    With the efficacy shown in the BA mouse model above, we foreshadowed that anti-CD20 treatment might be useful in infants with BA. Transient B cell depletion with rituximab (RTX) has been used to prevent allograft rejection after liver transplantation in infants with BA (Egawa et al., 2007
    16.
    Egawa, H. ∙ Ohmori, K. ∙ Haga, H. ...
    B-cell surface marker analysis for improvement of rituximab prophylaxis in ABO-incompatible adult living donor liver transplantation
    Liver Transpl. 2007; 13:579-588
    Crossref
    Scopus (90)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Usuda et al., 2005
    87.
    Usuda, M. ∙ Fujimori, K. ∙ Koyamada, N. ...
    Successful use of anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody (rituximab) for ABO-incompatible living-related liver transplantation
    Transplantation. 2005; 79:12-16
    Crossref
    Scopus (84)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). To test the safety and efficacy of RTX, we conducted an open-label pilot clinical study. Four infants with BA were recruited for treatment. We found that a single dose of RTX (187.5 mg/m2) was safe and was not associated with severe adverse events after drug administration. On average, the peripheral and liver-derived B cells were effectively depleted 1 day after RTX administration, and B cell recovery occurred 2–3 months following RTX administration (Figure 7A; Figures S7A–S7C). RTX treatment halted rising of Ro/SSA-IgG concentrations in the 4 trial subjects compared to the 14 BA subjects without RTX treatment (Figure 7B).
    To uncover immune changes following RTX treatment, we obtained scRNA-seq data from 3 RTX-treated trial subjects. Transcriptomic, TCR, and BCR data of 42,254 single cells were obtained, and 42 clusters were annotated as described above. BCR analysis showed that B cells with CD20 expression were effectively depleted in all patients treated with RTX, whereas the RAG1/2+ B cells and PCs were not significantly affected (Figure 7C). Furthermore, RTX treatment significantly decreased the frequency and clonal expansion of CD8Trm cells (Figure 7D). Clonal transition between the CX3CR1+CD8Teff and CD8Trm cells was also significantly decreased (Figure 7D).
    Transcriptome wide, RTX treatment increased CX3CR1 and cytotoxic gene (GZMA GZMB) expression in CX3CR1+CD8Teff cells but decreased IFNG expression in CD8Trm cells. Monocytes from the RTX-treated patients displayed increased expression of inflammasome components (PYCARD and IL1B), whereas Kupffer cells showed increased scavenger (MARCO and CD5L) and liver regenerative (CXCL12) (Liepelt and Tacke, 2016
    48.
    Liepelt, A. ∙ Tacke, F.
    Stromal cell-derived factor-1 (SDF-1) as a target in liver diseases
    Am. J. Physiol. Gastrointest. Liver Physiol. 2016; 311:G203-G209
    Crossref
    Scopus (85)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) function (Figure 7E). Additionally, expressions of Th17 signature genes (KLRB1, RORC, and CCR6) were increased in ex-cTh17 cells (Figure S7E). It should be mentioned that RTX treatment also decreased the expression of genes associated with T cell co-inhibition (PDCD1, LAG3, and CTLA4) in cTh1 and ex-cTh17 cells (Figure S7E). The significance of these changes after RTX treatment is currently unknown. Overall, however, transient B cell depletion might serve as a pre- or post-operational strategy to restore liver immune cell function in infants with BA (Figure 7F).

    Discussion

    We showed that patients with BA had persistently elevated DBIL, TBAs, liver enzymes (r-GT, ALT, and AST) and IgG4: IgM ratio. Liver damage was correlated with both immune-mediated destruction and reduced immune restoration. For the former, infants with BA had increased cytotoxic-type immunity (CD8Trm and Th1) but decreased Th17-type immunity (cTh17, MAIT17, and γδT17). ex-Th17 cells had previously been shown to play pathogenetic roles in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (Basdeo et al., 2015

    ) and the activation and tolerance mechanisms, as well as the clinical relevance of these findings to other pediatric liver and autoimmune diseases, warrant further studies.
    We also demonstrated that temporarily depleting B cells by a single dose of RTX was safe and well tolerated in infants with BA. RTX administration spared the pro-B cells and PCs but depleted immature, naive, and memory B cells from circulation and liver of infants with BA. The beneficial effects are likely manifold, including halting the increase of IgG autoantibodies and preventing the expansion of cytotoxic T cells. Additional unexpected advantageous outcomes include increasing the inflammatory potential of macrophages, promoting the repairing function of CX3CR1+CD8Teff and cir-NK cells, and restoring the scavenger and regenerative function of Kupffer cells.
    In summary, we provide comprehensive immune pathogenic mechanisms that can lead to rapid liver failure in infants with BA. In particular, we propose that B-cell-modifying therapies may ameliorate BA pathology.

    Experimental Model and Subject Details

    Ethical statement

    The Medical Ethics Committee of Guangzhou Women and Children’s Medical Center approved the study procedures and clinical trial (ID: 201948701). The implementations were in concordance with the International Ethical Guidelines for Research Involving Human Subjects as stated in the Helsinki Declaration. The legal guardians of all participants signed the consent forms.

    Participants

    The electronic medical records (EMRs) of children with BA (n = 927), CC (n = 248), physiological jaundice (n = 9,297) and non-disease control subjects (n = 2,471) between January 2011 to August 2019 were retrospectively examined. Baseline demographics, laboratory test results and clinical outcomes of these subjects were retrieved.
    To study immune pathogenesis, a cohort of children from the Department of Pediatric Surgery at Guangzhou Women and Children’s Medical Center were enrolled between January 2019 and June 2020. BA (n = 152) (median age: 2 months, ranging from 1 month to 7 months; male/female = 0.92) was diagnosed when intrahepatic biliary tree and/or extrahepatic bile duct could not be observed with intraoperative cholangiography. For controls, children with normal liver function but requiring surgery for choledochal cyst (CC) (n = 63) (median age: 25 months, ranging from 2 months to 12 years; male/female = 0.43) or non-cholestatic diseases (n = 35) (median age: 4 years, ranging from 1 months to 13 years; male/female = 1.06) were included.
    For assessing the therapeutic effects of Rituximab, an open label clinical study was conducted in 4 patients with BA. Rituximab was administered at 187.5 mg/m2 5-7 days before or after the Kasai’s operation. The postoperative (PO) course involved nasogastric drainage and intravenous fluids until there was evidence of bowel function. Ursodeoxycholic acid (10-15 mg/kg bid PO) was added after the infants had begun normal feeding. Methylprednisolone injection was given 5th −7th days PO at 4 mg/kg qd followed by 2 mg/kg qd, and tablets were given orally 2 mg/kg qd for 3 weeks. Cefoperazone and metronidazole were administered for 10-14 days PO. Cefixime and TMPco were alternately administered for 6 months to minimize the risk of cholangitis. Blood B cell counts, laboratory indices and adverse events were monitored before, during and after Rituximab administration.

    Mice

    The animal studies were approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee of Guangzhou Medical University (ID: 2019-471). BALB/c mice were purchased from Laboratory Animal Center of Guangdong Province. Breeding pairs (1 male and 2 or 3 female mice) were housed in microisolator cages in laminar flow hoods. Maximized number of pregnancies were obtained within the same week. Once the females were pregnant, they were placed into separate housings. All newborn pups (aged 1 day) were randomly assinged to control, RRV and therapeutic groups. All experimental procedures were carried out according to the institutional guidelines.

    Cell lines

    LX-2 cells obtained from ATCC were grown in RPMI1640, supplemented with 10% (v/v) FBS, 2 mM glutamine and 1% (v/v) Penicillin-Streptomycin at 37°C in 5% CO2 at 100% humidity.

    Human lymphocytes

    Immune cells from peripheral blood and liver biopsies were isolated by flow-cytometry based sorting.

    Method Details

    Characterization of clinical indices for control subjects and infants with BA

    The LASSO-regression model was applied to identify BA specific clinical indices. Only indices with records in more than 20% of the 12,943 EMR reports were included in the machine learning process. A subset of 10% of the subjects was randomly selected as the dataset for training process. The 58 significant coefficients (clinical indices) determined by the regression model were selected as group specific parameters. Among those 58 coefficients, the r-GT, ALT, AST, TBA and DBIL showed significantly elevated levels in infants with BA, which was consistent with clinical consensus (Figure 1A). The rest 90% of the subjects were utilized to validate the predictive performance of the BA-specific clinical indices to distinguish children with BA from CC, physiologic jaundice and non-diseased control subjects (Figure S1B).

    Hepatic biopsy processing

    Liver biopsies were obtained from patients during laparoscopy or Kasai’s operation. The specimens were collected in sterile phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) supplemented with 0.5% BSA and 1 mM EDTA (pH = 8.0) (FACS buffer). Each sample was sent for histological assessment and the sparing tissue was used for the isolation of intrahepatic lymphocytes. Specifically, hepatic tissues (0.05-0.2 g) were washed three times with FACS buffer to eliminate blood contaminations and remove intravascular lymphocytes. Samples were transferred onto 70 μm cell strainers pre-wetted with 2 mL FACS buffer that were placed in 50 mm Petri dishes, cut into < 1 mm3 pieces with ophthalmic scissors and minced gently with plunger of 1 mL insulin syringe. An extra 2 mL FACS buffer was added to wash the cell strainer. A total 4 mL cell suspensions were filtered through cell strainer (Falcon, Round-Bottom Tubes with Cell Strainer Cap). To remove majority of the hepatocytes, cells were centrifuged at 50 × g for 2 min. The supernatant was collected for further centrifugation at 1800 rpm for 5 min. The supernatant (liver homogenates) was saved in −80 þC freezer for further laboratory tests. Cell pellets were re-suspended with 1-2 mL red cell lysis buffer for 5 min at room temperature (RT). Prior to centrifugation, 10 mL FACS buffer was added to stop the reaction. Cell pellets were re-suspended in 10 mL 35% Percoll for centrifugation at 2000 rpm for 30 min at 4þC. The resulted cell pellets (lymphocytes) were washed once in PBS and re-suspended in FACS buffer, which were ready for phenotypic flow cytometry assays.

    Hepatic immune cell phenotype analysis

    Peripheral blood mononuclear cells or hepatic lymphocytes were incubated for 45 min at 4þC with saturating concentrations of fluorescently labeled antibodies and analyzed on a FACSAria SORP flow cytometer (BD Science). For T cell phenotype analysis, cells were stained with anti-CD45, CD3, CD8a, CD4, CD25, CX3CR1, CD69, CD45RA, CCR7 antibodies. The proportions of CX3CR1+CD8Teff cells (CD45+CD3+CD8+CD4-CD45RA+CCR7-CX3CR1+CD69+/−), CD69+CD8+Trm cells (CD45+CD3+CD8+CD4-CD45RA-CCR7+CX3CR1-CD69+) in CD8+ T cell cells were analyzed. For B cell phenotype analysis, cells were stained with anti-CD45, CD3, CD19, CD20, CD10, CD71, CD38, IgD, IgM, CD34, CD138, CD21, CD27, FCRL5, IgG, IgA antibodies. B cells at differentiation stages in liver were identified by surface markers as described previously (Bendall et al., 2014
    5.
    Bendall, S.C. ∙ Davis, K.L. ∙ Amir, A.D. ...
    Single-cell trajectory detection uncovers progression and regulatory coordination in human B cell development
    Cell. 2014; 157:714-725

    Multiplex cytometric bead assay for determination and quantification of immunoglobulins

    Immunoglobins (IgG1, IgG2, IgG3, IgG4, IgA, IgM, IgD and IgE) in plasma, liver homogenates and cell culture supernatants were measured by LEGENDplex cytometric bead array (CBA) immunoassays for Human Immunoglobulin Isotyping Panel according manufacturer’s protocols (Biolegend). Liver homogenates had undergone high speed centrifugation (13,000 r.p.m, 5min, 4þC) and supernatants were collected and tested without dilution. Plasma and cell culture supernatants were diluted 5 times for immunoglobulin assay. Samples were incubated with the bead mixture and secondary antibodies for 2 hours. Detection antibodies were added and incubated for another 30 minutes. Beads were washed and resuspended in wash buffer and analyzed using FACSAria flow cytometer (BD Science).
    Immunoglobulin concentration in liver were expressed in terms of mg protein estimated from Bradford protein concentration in respective liver homogenates samples using BCA protein assay kit (Beyotime Biotechnology) according to the procedure provided by the manufacturer.

    Multiplex assays of cytokines

    The concentrations of 64 cytokines, chemokines and growth factors in plasma and liver homogenates samples from Ctrl-other, Ctrl-CC and BA groups were analyzed by quantitative cytokine assays using Bio-plex Pro human cytokine standard 27-plex and human inflammation panel 1,37-plex panels according to the pre-optimized protocols provided by the manufacturer (Bio-Rad Laboratory). Liver homogenates had undergone high speed centrifugation (13,000 r.p.m, 5min, 4 þC), and supernatants were collected for the tests. Data were collected and analyzed using a Bio-Rad Bio-Plex 200 instrument equipped with Bio-Plex Manager software version 6.0 (Bio-Rad Laboratory). The precision based on both intra and inter-assays variations were < 10% within the detection limits provided by the manufacturer. The immunoassay data in liver were expressed in terms of per mg protein estimated from Bradford protein concentration in respective liver homogenates samples using BCA protein assay kit (Beyotime Biotechnology).

    Detection and quantification of autoantibodies by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISA)

    96-well Clear Polystyrene Microplates (Corning®) were coated overnight at 4 þC with 100 μL recombinant antigens (10 μg/mL) in PBS. After washing with PBS-T (PBS + 0.05% Tween20), the plates were blocked with 10% FBS in PBS-T (200 μL) for 2 hours and washed thoroughly with PBS-T. 100 μL of the serum dilution (1:100 in PBS) and liver homogenates were added to the plates for 1h at RT with agitation. After similar washing, 100 μL alkaline phosphatase-conjugated rabbit anti-human IgG or IgM diluted 1:1000 in PBS-T were added and incubated for 1 h at RT with agitation. After three washes, the alkaline-phosphatase activity was developed with 100 μL of p-nitrophenylphosphate (Sigma) at 1 mg/mL in 1 mL diethanolamine buffer (pH 9.8) for 1 h at RT. The mean optical density (OD) for each sample was measured on ELISA reader (Bio-rad) at 450 nm. Results of serum were expressed in ELISA activity units, whereas results of liver homogenates were expressed in ELISA activity units in terms of per mg protein.

    Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISA)

    CX3CL1 (Abcam) and C1Q (Cloud-Clone Corp) in plasma and liver homogenates were quantified using commercial ELISA kits according to the manufacturers’ instructions. Liver homogenates were centrifuged at 13,000 r.p.m 4 þC for 5 min and supernatants were collected for ELISA measurement. Intrahepatic CX3CL1 and C1Q concentrations were normalized to per μg or mg of total protein.

    Phagocytosis of fluorescent labeled E. coli by Kupffer cells

    Single cell suspensions for liver samples were prepared and seeded onto a 96-well plate (2 × 106/well) followed by incubation with 5 μL/well E. coli slurry for 2 hours in the cell incubator. After washing the wells three times with ice-cold Phagocytosis Assay Buffer, cells from human samples were surface-stained with CD68 and VSIG4, and cells from mice were surface-stained with CD45, CD3, CD19, CD11b, F4/80, Iy6G, Ly6C. Gating strategies for human and mice Kupffer cells were shown in Figures 4E and S6E, respectively. Stained cells were analyzed immediately with a FACSCalibur. Prior to flow cytometric acquisition, PI was added for exclusion of dead cells. The phagocytosis activity was expressed as proportion of FITC+ Kupffer cells.

    Chromatin Immunoprecipitation (ChIP)

    The cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) technology was utilized with modifications to pulldown ASCL2-binding chromatin regions (Kaya-Okur et al., 2019
    35.
    Kaya-Okur, H.S. ∙ Wu, S.J. ∙ Codomo, C.A. ...
    CUT&Tag for efficient epigenomic profiling of small samples and single cells
    Nat. Commun. 2019; 10:1930
    Crossref
    Scopus (987)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Briefly, Concanavalin A-coated magnetic beads (ConA beads) (10 μL per sample) were activated by washing with Binding Buffer (20 mM HEPES pH7.5, 10 mM KCl, 1 mM MnCl2, 1 mM CaCl2) twice and gently re-suspended in Binding Buffer. NK cells were sorted from human cord blood and washed with ice-cold PBS twice. Around 2 × 105 cells were washed with 1 mL Wash Buffer (250 mM NaCl, 0.5 mM Spermidine, 20 mM HEPES pH7.5, 1 × Protease inhibitor cocktail) and centrifuged at 1,600 r.p.m for 5 min at RT. Cells were re-suspended with 100 μL Wash Buffer, gently mixed with 10 μL activated ConA beads, and incubated at RT for 15 min. The bead-bound cells were rinsed with magnetic stand and res-suspended with 50 μL ice-cold antibody buffer (20 mM HEPES pH7.5, 150 mM NaCl, 0.5 mM Spermidine, 0.05% Digitonin, 2 mM EDTA, 0.1% BSA, 1 × Protease inhibitor cocktail) supplemented with 1 μL anti-ASLC2 antibody. The cell-beads-antibody mixture was incubated at RT for 2 hours with gentle rotation. 1st antibody was removed with magnetic stand. 2nd antibody (1 μg) were diluted in 50 μL of Dig-wash buffer (20 mM HEPES pH7.5, 150 mM NaCl, 0.5 mM Spermidine, 0.05% Digitonin, 1 × Protease inhibitor cocktail). Cells were incubated in the 2nd antibody solution for 1 hour at RT. Cells were washed three times with Dig-wash buffer and incubated with 0.04 μM Hyperactive pA-Tn5 Transposase adaptor complex mix (TTE mix) in 100 μL of Dig-300 buffer (20 mM HEPES pH7.5, 300 mM NaCl, 0.5 mM Spermidine, 0.01% Digitonin, 1 × Protease inhibitor cocktail) at RT for 1 hour. Cells were then washed three times with Dig-300 buffer and resuspended in 300 μL of tagmentation buffer (10 mM MgCl2 in Dig-300 buffer) and incubated at 37 þC for 1 hour. Tagmentation was terminated by adding 10 μL of 0.5 M EDTA, 3 μL of 10% SDS and 5 μL of 10 mg/mL Proteinase K to the sample and incubated at 50 þC for 1 hour. DNA was purified with phenol-chloroform-isoamyl alcohol extraction and ethanol precipitation, followed by SYBR qPCR detection.
    HEK293T cells with transient expression of Flag-tagged KLF2 were used for ChIP assay as there’s no usable IP-grade anti-KLF2 antibody. ChIP assay was performed using a ChIP assay kit (Beyotime Biotechnology) according to manufacturer’s instructions. HEK293T cells with overexpression of KLF2-3 × Flag were fixed with 1% formaldehyde for 10 min at 37 þC. The anti-Flag antibody was applied for immunoprecipitation.

    RNA-seq library construction for 10x Genomics single cell 5' and V(D)J sequencing

    Liver Biopsies from 19 children (6 Ctrl-CC, 4 Ctrl-other, 6 BA, and 3 BA receiving RTX treatment) were processed following the steps above. Single cell suspensions were subsequently stained with antibody (CD45-BV421, 0.5 μL/106 cells), after which they were sorted into Eppendorf tubes that were pre-wetted with fetal bovine serum (FBS) using a FACSAria SORP flow cytometer (BD Science). Dead cells were excluded by propidium iodide (PI). Single-cell 5’ RNA sequencing libraries for each of the 21 samples were separately constructed for immune (CD45+) cells according to the protocols of the Chromium Single Cell 5' Library kit (10x GENOMICS). Briefly, single-cell suspension mixed with RT-PCR master mix was loaded with partitioning oil and nanoliter-scale gel beads into a single-cell 5’ chip according to the manufacturer’s instructions. To generate a single multiplexed library, RNA transcripts were uniquely barcoded within single cells and reverse-transcribed into barcoded cDNAs, which were purified, amplified, end-repaired, and ligated with illumine adapters. TCR- and BCR- enriched libraries were generated with aliquots from each of the aforementioned cDNAs using the Chromium Single Cell V(D)J Enrichment kit. All the libraries were sequenced on the Illumina Novaseq 6000 platform.

    Single-cell RNA-seq data pre-processing

    The off-machine 5¢-expression sequencing data was demultiplexed and aligned to the human transcriptome (build GRCh38) using the Cell Ranger v2.1.1 (10x Genomics). The generated outputs for the 21 samples were pooled to obtain a combined raw expression matrix (gene counts versus cells) using the function cellranger aggr. The unique molecular identifier (UMI) count matrix was transformed into Seurat objects using the R package Seurat v 3.1.2 (Butler et al., 2018
    10.
    Butler, A. ∙ Hoffman, P. ∙ Smibert, P. ...
    Integrating single-cell transcriptomic data across different conditions, technologies, and species
    Nat. Biotechnol. 2018; 36:411-420
    Crossref
    Scopus (6227)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Stuart et al., 2019
    79.
    Stuart, T. ∙ Butler, A. ∙ Hoffman, P. ...
    Comprehensive Integration of Single-Cell Data
    Cell. 2019; 177:1888-1902.e1821
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (7328)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Qualified cells with detected gene number between 200 and 5,000, UMI number below 50,000 and percentage of mitochondrial genes below 12.5% were kept. After quality control, a dataset of 159,622 cells × 21,173 genes were obtained for downstream analysis. The raw gene expression measurements for each cell were normalized by dividing them by the total expression followed by scale factor-multiplying ( × 10,000) and log-transformation In (UMI-per-10,000+1) with the function NormalizeData in the Seurat toolkit.

    Cell type classification using an integrated reference

    To eliminate batch effects, a reference Seurat object was generated by identifying anchor genes between samples. Briefly, we split the combined Seurat object into a list of Seurat objects with each dataset as an element by running the command of SplitObject. Each Seurat dataset within the list was normalized for identification of variable genes by running NormalizeData and FindVariableFeatures (xxx, selection.method = “vst,” nfeatures = 2000). Next, anchors were identified using the command FindIntegrationAnchors (object.list = BA.list, dims = 1:30). These anchors were then passed to the function IntegrateData (anchorset = anchors, dims = 1:30), which returned a Seurat object holding an integrated batch effects corrected expression matrix. An “integrated” assay with the integrated expression matrix was contained in the Seurat object. The original uncorrected values were stored in the object in the “RNA” assay, ready to be switched back and forth.
    The new integrated expression matrix was used for downstream analysis. First, we scaled the integrated data for PCA and tSNE visualization. The cells were then clustered by cell type, rather than by batch effects. Major cell types (T cells, B cells and plasma cells, Natural killer (NK) and NKT cells, and myeloid cells) were identified by mapping canonical marker genes in the two-dimensional t-SNE map (Tables S1 and S2).
    The cell identities for Seurat object generated with cells from two BA infants treated with Rituximab were determined by the methods of label transfer in Seurat v 3.1.2. Briefly, transferred anchors between the reference Seurat object and objects from Rituximab group were calculated using anchorset = FindTransferAnchors (reference = BA, query = query_obj, dims = 1:30). Predicted cell identities were determined by passing the anchorset mentioned above to the function TransferData (anchorset = anchorset, refdata = BA.downsample$cluster, dims = 1:30).

    Analysis of functional cellular subsets within the major cell types

    Functional sub-clusters within each of major cell types were partitioned and analyzed. We performed PCA using the variably expressed genes for each of the major cell type objects under “integrated” assay mode. Significant principal components, selected by looking at the elbow position on standard deviation graphs of PCAs, were used for subsequent clustering and t-SNE visualization. Seurat function FindClusters was utilized with suitable resolution to identify sub-clusters within each major cell type. Cells with expression of double-lineage genes, including CD3+CD19+ cells, CD68+CD19+ cells, were excluded to eliminate potential doublet capture bias. Differentially expressed genes (DEGs) for each of the sub-clusters were identified using FindAllMarkers function under RNA assay mode. The test method used for FindAllMarkers was the Wilcoxon rank sum test. We defined each cell sub-cluster based on the expression of canonical markers (Table S1). Any transcriptomic comparisons, e.g., between control and BA, between liver and PBMC group, were performed using function FindMarkers (object = obj, ident.1 = ident.1, ident.2 = ident.2, verbose = FALSE) under RNA assay mode.

    Pesudo time trajectory analysis

    Single-cell trajectory analysis was performed with the Monocle package (v2.8.0) (Qiu et al., 2017
    71.
    Qiu, X. ∙ Mao, Q. ∙ Tang, Y. ...
    Reversed graph embedding resolves complex single-cell trajectories
    Nat. Methods. 2017; 14:979-982
    Crossref
    Scopus (2116)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). The starting subject CellDataSet class was created with normalized expression cells × genes matrix. The DEGs across sub-clusters were identified by performing differentialGeneTest function and subsequently used as genes to define cell progress. DDRTree incorporated in the reduceDimension function was applied for data dimension reduction. Cells were then ordered in pesudotime with the orderCells function. The trajectory was visualized in two-dimensional space by running plot_cell_trajectory function.

    Transcription factor activity analysis

    To measure TF activity, SCENIC (Aibar et al., 2017
    1.
    Aibar, S. ∙ González-Blas, C.B. ∙ Moerman, T. ...
    SCENIC: single-cell regulatory network inference and clustering

    ) was applied to deduce gene regulatory networks across cell clusters. Briefly, genes co-expressed with TFs were identified using the function runGenie3 in the GENIE3 package. The aforementioned co-expressed genes were converted into co-expression modules by running the function runSCENIC_1_coexNetwork2modules. Potential direct-binding target genesets (regulons) were identified using the function runSCENIC_2_createRegulons implemented in RcisTarget package. The regulon activity was then scored for each cell by performing runSCENIC_3_scoreCells function in the R package AUCell. The AUCell matrices were retrieved for heatmap plotting. Genie3Weight values for pairs of TF-target genes were utilized for regulatory network analysis and visualization with Cytoscape (v3.7.0) (Shannon et al., 2003
    75.
    Shannon, P. ∙ Markiel, A. ∙ Ozier, O. ...

    ).

    TCR and BCR analysis

    Single-cell sequencing data of BCR and TCR were analyzed with the cellranger vdj pipeline with parameter setting of –chain = IG and –chain = TR, respectively. cellranger vdj pipeline performs V(D)J sequence assembly and paired cell-by-cell clonotype calling. The outputs of cellranger vdj include the productive nucleotide sequences and translated amino acid sequences of the CDR3 region for TCRs (a and b chains) and BCRs (heavy and light chains). The information of TCR or BCR for each cell was matched with its 5¢ expression data via the unique cellular barcode. A clonotype was defined as identical CDR3 sequences of a-b TCR pair or heavy-light BCR pair. Cells with the same clonotype were identified as clonal TCRs or BCRs. Mucosal-associated invariant T cells (MAIT) with a chain composed of V segment TRAV1-2 were excluded from the downstream analysis.
    1)
    Clonal expansion Cells with the same clonotype ID within one T or B cell sub-cluster were counted for each sample. Percentage of expanded clonotype (Pexp) was calculated as below:
    Pexp=∑𝑚𝑖=1𝑛⁢𝑖𝑁×100⁢%,in which
    m: number of clonotype ID with attributed cell number > = 2;
    ni: attributed cell number for clonotype i;
    N: total cell number in a sub-cluster for a sample.
    Two-sided Student’s t test was applied for Pexp comparison between control and BA group. The mean Pexp value for each sub-cluster from control or BA group was calculated and used for heatmap plotting.
    2)
    Clonal transition Percentage of clonal transition between any two (C1 and C2) of the T or B cell sub-clusters for each sample (Ptran C1-C2) was calculated as below:
    PtranC⁢1−C⁢2=∑𝑚𝑖=1(𝑛⁢𝑖−𝐶⁢1+𝑛⁢𝑖−𝐶⁢2)𝑁,inwhich
    m: kinds of clonotype IDs with presence in both C1 and C2;
    ni-C1: attributed cell number for clnonotype i in C1;
    ni-C2: attributed cell number for clonotype i in C2;
    N: total T or B cell number from one sample
    Mean Ptran values were calculated for BA and control group and subjected for network plotting with Cytoscape (v3.7.0).
    3)
    BCR V × J rearrangement index During B cell development, gene loci encoding light chain BCRs undergo frequent VJ recombination events. If light chain generated from primary recombination turns out to be inefficient to erase autoreactivity, the IgL locus would initiate secondary recombination to increase the chance to produce non-autoreactive BCR. Primary recombination is prone to take place between v- and j-gene adjacent to thev-j boundary, while secondary recombination would occur at v- and j-gene relatively remote to the v-j boundary. Based on the assumption, we defined the BCR V × J rearrangement index to continuously measure the likelihood of a given light chain is derived from advanced V × J recombination. For the light chain of a given BCR, the V × J rearrangement index was calculated as below:
    V×J−index=order−v×order−j,inwhich
    order-v: the order of the given v gene among v-genes loci on human chromosome.
    order-j: the order of the given j gene among j-genes loci on human chromosome.
    4)
    Analysis of the autoimmune characteristics of BCR repertoires CDR3 length and number of positive charged amino acids within CDR3 region were counted for each heavy chain and compared between BA and control group. For each BCR, number of mutated nucleotides within Fv region in comparison with respective reference germline sequence were counted.

    Cell-cell communication analysis

    We employed a method called CellPhoneDB tailored for single-cell transcriptome data to explore cell-cell communications based on the manually curated repository of interacting ligands and receptors (https://www.cellphonedb.org; Vento-Tormo et al., 2018
    90.
    Vento-Tormo, R. ∙ Efremova, M. ∙ Botting, R.A. ...
    Single-cell reconstruction of the early maternal-fetal interface in humans
    Nature. 2018; 563:347-353
    Crossref
    Scopus (1309)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Briefly, the method infers potential cell-cell interactions based on expression of interacting ligand-receptor pairs between two clusters. The gene encoding receptor or ligand included in the downstream analysis should be expressed by more than 30% cells in a specific cluster. To identify the significance of a ligand-receptor pair between two clusters, the permutation test was performed by randomly assigning the cluster labels of each cell for 1,000 times. An empirical P value was determined by the rank of actual average expression of a given ligand and receptor pair in two clusters among the 1,000 permutated results.

    Bulk RNaseq

    Total RNA extraction, reverse transcription, and preamplification were performed with Discover-scTM WTA Kit V2 (Vazyme). RNA purity, concentration, and integrity were determined by NanoDrop® spectrophotometers (Thermo Fisher, MA, USA), Qubit® RNA assay kit on Qubit® 3.0 Flurometer (Life technologies, CA, USA), and RNA Nano 6000 Assay kit of the Bioanalyzer 2100 system (Agilent Technologies, CA, USA), respectively. Library was prepared using VAHTS mRNA-seq v2 library Prep Kit for Illumina® (Vazyme, NR601) following manufacturer’s instructions. The libraries were then sequenced on Illumina Hiseq X Ten platform with 150 bp paired-end module. Clean reads were obtained by filtering the raw reads with cutadapt (v1.2) (Martin, 2011
    59.
    Martin, M.
    Cutadapt removes adapter sequences from high-throughput sequencing reads
    EMBnet J. 2011; 17:10
    Crossref
    Google Scholar
    ). Clean reads were aligned to reference genome (GRCh38) using Hisat2 (v2.0.5) (Kim et al., 2015
    38.
    Kim, D. ∙ Langmead, B. ∙ Salzberg, S.L.
    HISAT: a fast spliced aligner with low memory requirements
    Nat. Methods. 2015; 12:357-360
    Crossref
    Scopus (13773)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Pertea et al., 2016
    70.
    Pertea, M. ∙ Kim, D. ∙ Pertea, G.M. ...
    Transcript-level expression analysis of RNA-seq experiments with HISAT, StringTie and Ballgown
    Nat. Protoc. 2016; 11:1650-1667
    Crossref
    Scopus (3950)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). The mapped reads of each sample were assembled using Stringtie (v1.3.3) with a reference-based approach (Pertea et al., 2016
    70.
    Pertea, M. ∙ Kim, D. ∙ Pertea, G.M. ...
    Transcript-level expression analysis of RNA-seq experiments with HISAT, StringTie and Ballgown
    Nat. Protoc. 2016; 11:1650-1667
    Crossref
    Scopus (3950)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Gene counts were quantified for each sample using the R package Rsubread (v2.0.1) with bam files as the input (Liao et al., 2019
    47.
    Liao, Y. ∙ Smyth, G.K. ∙ Shi, W.
    The R package Rsubread is easier, faster, cheaper and better for alignment and quantification of RNA sequencing reads
    Nucleic Acids Res. 2019; 47:e47
    Crossref
    Scopus (1334)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) and subsequently subjected to differential expressed genes (DEGs) calling using DESeq2 (v1.18.1) (absolute log2FoldChange > = 1, adjusted p value < 0.05) (Love et al., 2014
    51.
    Love, M.I. ∙ Huber, W. ∙ Anders, S.

    ). The Cuffdiff (v1.3.0) was applied to calculate Fragments Per Kilobase of exon per Million fragments mapped (FPKMs) for coding genes in each sample (Trapnell et al., 2012
    83.
    Trapnell, C. ∙ Roberts, A. ∙ Goff, L. ...

    ).

    Quantification and Statistical Analysis

    R v3.5.3 (Foundation for Statistical Computing) was applied for the statistical analyses and graphics production with scRNA-seq data. For the experimental data, GraphPad Prism 7 (GraphPad Software) was used to perform statistical analyses and graphics production. All the statistical analyses were performed in two-sided manner. Detailed descriptions of statistical tests are speciðed in the Results section and in the Figure Legends.

    You may choose not to allow some types of cookies. However, blocking some types may impact your experience of our site and the services we are able to offer. See the different category headings below to find out more or change your settings.

    Manage Consent Preferences

    Strictly Necessary Cookies

    Always active

    These cookies are necessary for the website to function and cannot be switched off in our systems. They are usually only set in response to actions made by you which amount to a request for services, such as setting your privacy preferences, logging in or filling in forms. You can set your browser to block or alert you about these cookies, but some parts of the site will not then work. These cookies do not store any personally identifiable information.

    Functional Cookies

    These cookies enable the website to provide enhanced functionality and personalisation. They may be set by us or by third party providers whose services we have added to our pages. If you do not allow these cookies then some or all of these services may not function properly.

    Performance Cookies

    These cookies allow us to count visits and traffic sources so we can measure and improve the performance of our site. They help us to know which pages are the most and least popular and see how visitors move around the site.

    Targeting Cookies

    These cookies may be set through our site by our advertising partners. They may be used by those companies to build a profile of your interests and show you relevant adverts on other sites. If you do not allow these cookies, you will experience less targeted advertising.
